events.name: gnocode August Meetup
events.description:
This is our first event, so there will be lots of discussion about what we want the group to be.

6:00 PM - 8:00PM

events.name: gnocode September Meetup - Single Sign-on and Sugar on a Stick
events.description: Ryan Lane will present on the single sign-on and Dennis Daniels will introduce us to Sugar on a Stick.

events.name: gnocode October Meetup - jQuery
events.description:
Our topic for this month is the jQuery JavaScript library. If you have a favorite jQuery application, example or a question we hope you will share them with us after the main presentation.

We are slightly altering the format of our meeting to keep it shorter and more focused. You can see and read more at the website post.

events.name: Special Event with Brian Gorbett of Microsoft's BizSpark
events.description:
I have a special invitation to an event tomorrow night, November 11, 2009 with Brian Gorbett. Brian is with Microsoft's BizSpark program. He is also a big cloud computing advocate, so he should be a good forerunner to our Hash Table event next week.

The event is just an meet-and-greet at LaunchPad to show off what the New Orleans software development community is doing and to hear a bit about what they have going on at MicroSoft with BizSpark.

The event starts at 7:00 PM at LaunchPad, as usual. After a bit of easy conversation we will head over to Lucy's to continue.

Even if you aren't specifically interested in the BizSpark program, please come out and show your support. If you can make it please RSVP the event here.

You can find out more about Brian on his website: http://briangorbett.c...

events.name: Hash Table: The Cloud
events.description:
Update: Location finally picked: Jazmine Cafe on S. Carrollton at Riverbend.

I'm also looking for people to volunteer to lead discussion on certain aspects of our topic, like cost, security, performance, etc. Let us know on twitter, e-mail, the website or carrier pigeon.

This is our first Hash Table event and our topic will be "the Cloud". There are more details posted on our website.

Please RSVP soon, to help us plan the event.
events.how_to_find_us: We have a private room in the back right of the restaurant.

events.name: gnocode December Meetup - Search Algorithms and Memcached with team Turbo Squid
events.description:
This month some of the developers at Turbo Squid are going to share some the concepts, techniques and other juicy details of their recent rewrite of their search engine. They will focus on their search algorithm and their use of memcached.

Turbo Squid is a New Orleans based company that has created a digital market place for 3-D models and products.

events.name: Special Event: Ted Neward at GNO .NET user group
events.description:
This is a reminder that Ted Neward will present at the January 12th GNO .NET user group at New Horizon's in Metairie at 6:30PM. Ted is a highly regarded leader in software development, a blogger and an author. He specializes in .NET and Java technologies at the enterprise level, but I am certain he will provide plenty of good advice and info for anyone in software development.

I encourage everyone to come out and see him. I know I am a big fan of his and look forward to it. This is also a great opportunity to show a high profile member of the software development community the energy and community here in New Orleans.

Here are a couple of quick links about Ted and the event. I hope to see you then.

GNO .NET site
Form to help pick Ted's topic
Ted's Blog
About Ted
New Horizon's

Thanks,
Barrett M. Conrad

events.name: iPhone Development Quick Start Guide with Chris Van Buskirk of Calliope Digital
events.description:
Chris Van Buskirk of Calliope Digital is giving our first presentation of 2010. He will give us an overview of developing for the iPhone. Chris and Calliope developed the Who Dat App and the Mardi Gras Guide by Arthur Hardy.

http://www.calliopedi...

events.name: Special Event: CrisisCampNOLA
events.description:
UPDATE: Please use the EventBrite page to RSVP for this event http://crisiscampnola...

CrisisCamp is a national event to develop technology tools to assist in times of crisis--particularly in support of the recent Haitian earthquake disaster.

Some local community members are putting a local version together to bring our unique perspective to the group. This looks to be a great event to kickstart our service projects, for those who are interested. Everyone is invited to help whether they are a developer or not. There are list of potential needs below.

The event is still in the planning stages, so updates will be frequent through out the week.

Here are some additional resources about the event.

Wiki: http://wiki.crisiscom...

Google group: http://groups.google....

Types of roles: (All projects are listed on the wiki):
* Drupal
* Python
* PHP
* geospatial people
* french/creole translators
* mobile app work
* UI / UX
* Media wiki people
* Scribes for projects
* Social media people to scrape information across the web

events.name: Mardi Gras Parade Meetup
events.description:
We're going to do this meeting a little differently since its Mardi Gras.

First, we changed the date. We are meeting on the 10th instead of the 17th. (Who really wants to meet the day after Mardi Gras?)

Instead of our normal presentation and mingle, we are going to gather for the first New Orleans night parade of the season. We will meet at LaunchPad, as usual, and then off to the parade route a block up on St. Charles.

Hopefully this will give everyone a chance to meet some new people in our quickly growing group.

If you want to contribute some refreshments to the event please feel free to. It is a parade after all. You can post your contribution in the comments on gnocode website.

The spring and summer are already filling up with great presentations from our members, so check back after Mardi Gras.

events.name: gnocode March Meetup - Data Warehousing with Cade Roux
events.description:
Data Warehouses
A Whistle-Stop Tour

"I start with a quick review of the current state of data warehousing
including the benefits of the dimensional modeling (DM) approach and a
discussion of the epic struggle between the Kimball-ites and the
Inmon-ites. I demystify the terminology and address some specific
practical areas related to data warehousing.

Attendees currently using traditional relational or object database
techniques without any data warehousing experience or requirements
should gain a significant technical advantage by including DM-inspired
approaches in their tactical arsenal. DM approaches and hybrid
relational/dimensional approaches offer unique benefits for meeting
certain requirements elegantly, efficiently and cost-effectively."

events.name: Getting on Rails 3 with James Thompson
events.description:
An overview of the key new features in Rails 3 and what they mean for the popular web framework. Attention will be given to Bundler, ActiveRelation, JS Framework Agnosticism and framework modularity. If time allows we'll also look at the upgrade path from Rails 2 to 3.

James Thompson is our presenter for this month. He is a local freelance developer and organizer of the Ruby Bayou user group. http://rubybayou.com/...

events.name: Hash Table: How Flashy is tomorrow's web?
events.description:
Update: The location for this month's meeting is Slice Pizzeria at 5538 Magazine St for 7:00 PM. Please RSVP.

It's time again for another Hash Table.

For those that don't know: Hash Table is gnocode meeting where we discuss a "controversial" topic over dinner at a local restaurant.

Our topic this month is Flash, it's place and future on the web. Most people have probably seen Steve Jobs' recent "Thoughts on Flash". This has added to a growing controversy about what the web is and how non-html technologies like Flash affect it.

Here is some reading on the topic:

Steve Jobs' 'Thoughts on Flash'

Gawker writer "exchange" with Steve Jobs

Scribd switchs to HTML5 - TechCrunch

Flash is not a right

IE9 sides with HTML 5 and H.264 - MSDN

Adobe abandons iPhone tools- PC Mag

Hulu sticking with Flash - IntoMobile

The Future of Web Content: HTML 5, Flash and Mobile Apps - TechCrunch

Does HTML 5 Really Beat Flash? The Surprising Results of New Tests - ReadWriteWeb

events.name: Version Control Tools
events.description: An introduction to different version control tools like Mercurial, Git and Subversion.

events.name: Talent Dating
events.description:
This is a special event this month in partnership with Chris Schultz and LaunchPad. The idea is to bring together the people in the startup community seeking technical talent and those with the talents. The event will be held at Capdeville, which is right next door to LaunchPad. This event is in addition too our normal monthly meeting the same night.

You can read more about the idea of Talent Dating on LaunchPad's blog.

Please register for the event just so we can have a head count.

events.name: gnocode Birthday
events.description:
It's gnocode's first birthday, so we are having a party. We will have pizza, beer and drinks provided by Susco Solutions. There are also door prizes including a free month at LaunchPad's co-working. You can also vote for your favorite presentation from this year.

We will have a couple of group updates during the meeting, but we want to hear from you on where we take the group from here.

events.name: Member Quick Fire Talks
events.description:
This month we are trying a different formant, since we had a speaker cancelation. At our August meeting, a number of you suggested a meetup of short form talks from multiple members. Since the opportunity arose this month let's give it a shot.

So, if you have an a Python tip or an Apache trick or maybe a great HTML5 link you would like to share; or if you have some C# that just won't compile; or you want our opinions on your new Ruby arch or maybe you just want to blow of steam about something [Apple|Google|Microsoft|Oracel|etc] did... then this is your night.

events.name: Google App Engine with Douglas Finley
events.description: Douglas will present on his experiences working with the Google App Engine

events.name: Hash Table: Have Web Frameworks Delivered?
events.description:
This month's topic is "Have Web Frameworks Delivered? A discussion about how our code has gotten better...and worse."

It's time we had a good, old-fashion, flame war in gnocode and this might be the perfect topic for it. The weather looks like it will be great for conversation on Avenue Pub's balcony. Best of all, Avenue Pub knows we are coming and is excited to have us!

PLEASE NOTE: This meeting if at Avenue Pub on St. Charles instead of the usual LaunchPad location.

Also, please RSVP as soon as possible, so we can get them a decent count.

events.name: Rasmus Lerdorf at NolaPHP
events.description:
Here's a very special event for all you PHP coders out there. Coders in general actually.

NOLA PHP will host Rasmus Lerdorf, the creator of PHP, at their Monthly meeting on December 9th at 7:00 PM.

I'm adding the full description and link below, but you can RSVP to this gnocode event if you don't want to join their meetup.

Here is the full description and link:
"Ok, so we're NOT back on schedule for December. heh. We've changed the date for the December NOLAPHP MeetUp to 12/9 - but we have a VERY GOOD reason!

Rasmus Lerdorf, creator of the PHP programming language, will be joining us as a special guest! He will be in town, and sought out our group to join us for one of our meetups. The topic will most likely be his thoughts on the current state of PHP and where he thinks it's going, following by a QA session.

It's still at LaunchPad @ 7PM, but now on Thursday 12/9. And, for this special occasion, pizza, drinks and beer will be provided."

http://www.meetup.com...

Thanks,
Barrett M. Conrad

events.name: Synchronized Development for Distributed Teams
events.description:
This month George Mauer presents a follow-up to his "award" winning Mercurial talk with a presentation on developing with distributed teams.

"EPS Software/CoDE Consulting has a highly distributed team with developers in Houston, New Orleans, Knoxville, and Sao Paulo all working on overlapping parts of the same project. This talk, developed by George Mauer and Claudio Lassala for Houston Techfest 2010 will cover some of the tools and techniques used to keep the team synchronized and working together toward a common goal. "
events.how_to_find_us: Use the side door on Capdeville St.

events.name: gnocode Hack Attack
events.description:
Hack Attack is a free-form weekly get-together under the umbrella of GNOCode for hackers to dedicate time towards working on a new fun side projects and ideas outside of their normal work domain. By encouraging the start of side projects, the ideas is to inspire local hackers to expand their current working knowledge and have fun programming without limits.

The aim is to give hackers the physical location, the allotted time during the week, and the social support to do what they do best: actually code stuff. There are no official presentations / talks / panels / central projects / etc. - it is literally just a day set aside each week for you to dedicate yourself to writing code for fun together with your local fellow hackers.

You're of course free to come in and work on anything you want. Perhaps you want to contribute some code to your favorite open-source project, explore some new technology you've always been meaning to learn, or start a new tech-driven side business. Work on anything you want; the only requirement is that you come in ready to hack on something, and have some fun exploring technology.

There is also no set level of experience required to attend: it's open to all developers, both veterans and newbies. Also, Hack Attack is planning to meet every Monday (starting on the 17th) from 8:00pm to 10:00pm at Launchpad's suite 102, and, as there are no set presentations, you're welcome to come later and leave earlier if needed, it's up to you.

events.name: Announcing gnocode Hack Attack
events.description:
We're excited to announce about a new aspect of gnocode. Our own Joe Ellis has put together a great new way for coders and technologists around the city to get together: gnocode Hack Attack.

The first Hack Attack meeting is two days before our monthly meeting, so we thought we would let members showcase what they plan to work on during the sessions. If you would like to show of your latest project or pitch an idea to other members let us know and bring it out on Wednesday.

events.name: Demo CR-48 ChromeOS Notebook
events.why:
It's cool, and I have one.

ChromeOS is Google's new "cloud" OS built around the Chrome web browser to be Fast, Simple, and Secure.

The CR-48 Notebook is a piece of reference hardware provided to participants in the ChromeOS pilot program.

events.name: gnocode Monthly Meetup - "The Site Architecture You Can Edit"
events.description:
Ryan Lane will present:

"How the Wikimedia Foundation will use a new virtualizationÂ technology, OpenStack Nova, to allow its volunteer community toÂ participate in site operations, including the ability to make rootÂ level changes on the production cluster that operates sites such asÂ Wikipedia, and Wikimedia commons.

Â 

The talk will go over the virtualization technology, the managementÂ interface, the source control methods, and the community interactionÂ involved in this project.

events.name: LP Ignition Companies - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Update: Looks like we'll have folks from:

http://dydra.com/

http://gamebuilderstudio.com/

http://playbadger.com/

This month we have some unique guests and format. We've invited the companies of the inaugural class of the LP Ignition program to come and share their products with us.

But this isn't just a practice pitch session. The goal is for them to share their ideas and technology and answer your questions about them. You'll get insight into some of the new companies here in New Orleans and they get some of your expertise. (They're anxious to meet the local technical talent too.) And everyone gets beer. (Don't make me use the marquee tag.)

We plan to structure this in a panel/conversation format. That means we need some volunteers prepared to ask questions about the companies and their technology. Shoot us an e-mail if you are interested.Â 

Check out http://launchpadignition.com for more details.Â

events.name: Hash Table - Is JavaScript the language of the future?
events.description:
Our topic: "Is JavaScript the language of the future?"Â 

Oh yes, I did just ask that question.

Give it some thought. HTML 5 is full of JavaScript improvements. How frequently are you translating your database's info into JSON for client? How many new NoSQL databases use JSON and or JavaScript natively? So, why are our web applications written in some other language?Â 

Want more to chew on? Go read "Node.js and the JavaScript Age"Â andÂ "JavaScript creator talks about the future."

This month we are headed to the Rendon Inn.

See you there.

Â

events.name: gnocode Monthly Meetup: Reinstall
events.description:
Hello again gnocoders,

It's time for a change in gnocode. We first announced gnocode at BarCampNOLA 2009 and we've been very successful since then. As new groups have sprung up across the city for technology-specific user groups and hacking events, we have seen the community truly define itself. Our tech community is strong, but gnocode needs a revamp.

To do that we definitely want our members help, and that is the purpose of this month's meeting.Â 

Come on out and share some of your ideas for the group and let's keep our group growing.

And don't forget!Â  BarCampNOLA 2011 is on the calendar for July 16th and 17th. The Net2NO Minibar preview was great, so I'm sure the actually conference will be even better.Â

events.name: gnocode Monthly Meetup - noladex.org, Book Club, Code for America
events.description:
This month's meeting is all about kickstarting gnocode's maintenance of noladex.org which was created at this year's BarCampNOLA. It's already a resounding success, but there is so much more to do.Â 

We'll also talk about:

The Code for America fellow application do at the end of this month. Kicking off gnocode book club Some other things I can't remember at the moment. Â 

Â

events.name: gnocode Monthly Meetup - Book Club Discussion: Ruby, Io, Prolog
gnocode Monthly Meetup - Hack Dat Code Competition Kickoff
events.description:
This month we are going to kickoff the Hack Dat Code Competition coming this December.

Come join us at the Rendon Inn to learn more about the competition, and find a team for it.

Just bring yourself and that big idea you can't seem to let go.

events.name: gnocode - Big Table
events.description:
We've got something special for y'all this month.Â Free food and beer!

We want to spotlight our great software community this month so instead of Hash Table, we're having a Big Table! Join us for food and drinks sponsored by some great local companies and a celebrate software in New Orleans.Â 

Whether it's your first time to gnocode or you're a regular we'll see you then!

Thanks to our sponsors: iSeatz, LaunchPad Ignition, Susco Solutions, Touch Studios, TurboSquid, VoteIT.

(P.S. This will be a great time to find teammates for theÂ HackDatÂ code competition in December.)

(P.P.S. Please RSVP.)

events.name: Hack Dat Follow Up - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description:
The winners and other participants of the Hack Day competition will join us to show of their submissions.Â 

Â 

Â

events.name: Effectively using Git and Github in your projects - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Kurtis Rainbolt-Green is presenting this month on effectively using Git and Github in your processes. Or as he puts it:

"Sure you've worked hard to integrate with other developers on a social and even programming level, but what about your use of version control? Do you carefully distinguish between what exists on the server and what's in progress? What about keeping track of releases and hotfixes in a manageable and trackable way? Kurtis shows you how, why, and better what to use in order to gain that level of control with Git and Github Tao."

We'll also have refreshments (i.e. pizza, beer and drinks) courtesy of iSeatz this month.

events.name: LaunchPad Ignition Companies - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description:
It's entrepreneur season in New Orleans once again. This month we are welcoming a few of the companies from the LaunchPad Ignition startup accelerator to speak about their companies.Â 

This will be a great opportunity to hear about some of the new companies growing up in New Orleans and the technologies they are using.

We'll also have beer and snacks sponsored by the Ignition program.

Here's the full list of LPI 2012 companies:

connectforacause.com

giftmeo.com

home.kinobi.co

lawyerfy.com

redticketgames.com

unawkward.com

voteit.com

Â

events.name: "An Introduction to Haskell" - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Eric Normand is presenting this month "Introduction to World Domination using Haskell"

"Learn the basics of Haskell and get an inside look at what it's like to build a commercial product with it.

By the end of the talk, you will be able to: Build your own Haskell fortress (dev environment) from which to launch world-domination plans.

Forge Haskell programs with your bare hands.

Navigate the (sometimes) treacherous Haskell internet community

Enslave the type system to do your bidding.

Impress your friends with Monads

Eric Normand is a Haskell developer at Scrive (http://scrive.com). He was new to the language when he started 18 months ago and has learned a lot along the way. Learn from his mistakes or brave the language at your own peril!"

events.name: Unity 3d Game Development with Ian Fisch - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description: http://unity3d.com/ for more information.

events.name: Hash Table "What does it take to be a programmer?" - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description:
We're doing Hash Table this month and we think our topic will really get you going.

Let me ask you: "What does it take to be a programmer? Is it education? Training? Just experience?" Programmers come from all kinds of backgrounds and fill all kinds of roles. So, how do you know you are a programmer instead of just an tinkerer? What about an software engineer or architect?

I think you get the idea. Join us in the back room of Fat Harry's to really dive into the topic. We'll have beer specials from the bar and the first few pitches are on us, so get there early.

events.name: gnocode Monthly Meetup - 4.0 Schools Fellowship Tech Startups
events.description:
This month some of the fellows at 4.0 Schools are going to present/demo their edtech products and concepts. New Orleans is a hot bed for new ideas in education. This meetup will give you glimpse into what these edtech startups are working on and to share your technical expertise and feedback with them. Here's a bit about a few of the companies joining us:

"Classroom Blueprint is an online community where teachers share and discover best practices for classroom design. Teachers use our platform to publish their classroom spaces and the stories behind them, receiving colleagues' feedback and suggestions to further refine their setup. Leveraging this shared wisdom, teachers no longer need to waste precious time and resources recreating the wheel. Teachers -- new and experienced alike -- are able to efficiently find the best ideas and products to drive student achievement in their classrooms."

"Dash4Teachers is an iPhone app that allows Jedi teachers to create a daily list of parents to call and track data from those calls. Forgetting your clipboard or sticky notes, or even letting a student fall off your radar, will never be a problem again. Deborah Chang, who is a KIPP teacher that tested the app, commented, "This is the app I always wish I had! I'm using it now while teaching summer school, and it's been AMAZING. Imagine never having to worry about how to contact parents, again."

"Haystack EDU is best described as Consumer Reports meets match dot come for teacher jobs. The objective of the organization is to build a more efficient and effective market place for teacher jobs. The idea is to give both teachers and schools a better line of site into each other earlier in the hiring process so that they waste less time searching and ultimately end up with better matches."

"mangGO is a mobile phone application that helps parents easily track, reinforce, and reward their child's health habits and behaviors. Building healthy habits early in life significantly impacts a kid's immediate and long-term health. mangGO focuses on 4 health habits shown to make the greatest difference on a child's health: intake of fruits and veggies, soda consumption, screen time, and physical activity."

"My504HealthNet (name will likely change soon) is a mobile application that instantly links residents to low and no cost community based health care. In 3 clicks, users can find a doctor near them based on their insurance status, medical need, and location. Not only does linking people to a doctor improve their health outcomes, it largely saves money -- Interim LSU Hospital alone spent $13.1 million dollars last year in uncompensated care costs for preventable emergency room visits. In a region that ranks in the top 10% for density of primary care providers, My504HealthNet seeks to link area residents to these doctors to make us healthier and save money in the process."

Â

events.name: Clojure with Eric Normand
events.description:
Introduction to Clojure

Clojure is a functional, concurrency-friendly, and modern JVM-based language that is making waves in the wider programming world. Some have called it "the most powerful language on the JVM today".

In this talk, we will cover:

Syntax and Semantics Clojure Data Structures Functional programming Java Interop Concurrency primitives
See you there!

events.name: Transport for NOLA with Chris Boyd - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description: This month Chris Boyd from the Objective Crunk meetup group and Apptitude is going to share some of the work he's foing with Transport for NOLA.

events.name: GE Capital - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description: Our guests this month are some of the fine folks from the new GE Capital Technology Center here in New Orleans. They're going to share a bit about their focus and the opportunities with the company.

events.name: elasticsearch - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description: Dan Noble will be talking about using elasticsearch to handle analytics data.

events.name: Sublime Text - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description:
George Mauer presents:

I'm In Love With Sublime Text

It's a beginner talk that should apply equally to all skill levels and all languages. Here's the full synopsis:

Do you have a favorite text editor? Of course you do. For developers, a simple, lightweight text-editing tool is never far out of reach. So what's your poison? Notepad++? Ultraedit? Vim? Or are you just a plain-ol' Notepad fellow. Well never that mind cause after this lecture you won't be. Come check out Sublime Text. The new hotness in lightweight text editors that will make you fall in love.

Â

events.name: Node - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Benjamin Eckel will be talking about Node.js.

What is Node.js? How do I evaluate whether it's right for my project? Where does it fail? What are some good frameworks built on Node? Â

events.name: API Fears and IDE Loathing in New Orleans: Parse and Xcode
events.description: Barrett Conrad will be presenting: "A quick talk on building an iOS app with Parse and why Xcode isn't as bad as you think."

events.name: Maintainable CSS - gnocode Monthly Meetup
events.description:
Maintainable CSS.

While manageable when dealing with smaller apps, CSS can become a very annoying maintainence headache for medium to large scale applications. CSS cascades go awry, style reuse becomes non-existant, and everyone seems to hate dealing with it in general. Â Joe Ellis (@notjoeellis) will go through some best practices to show how to organize CSS into a comprehensible state and make your CSS development far faster and easier.

events.name: Apart in a Pair Tree - A remote pair programming story
events.description:
Pair programming is important because it fosters communication about code and improves code quality early in the lifecycle sometimes even faster than TDD. Remote pair programming is harder to accomplish, but is necessary as workplaces become composed of more distance workers. Learn why you should pair remotely and how to do it successfully through this fun story of my journey from cubicle land to productive remote pair guru.

Not so long ago, I worked in a shop where the evil cubicle overlords sought domination by dividing the developer minions into single person teams. The land was divided into cubicle egg crates that removed any communication other than that which happened in hours long meetings. The developers were isolated and cut off from the world. They used headphones to block out any attempts at communication. Terms like "Advancement of craft" and "Pursuit of exciting new languages" were never spoken.

As a lone developer, seated in a corner cubicle, I broke free and commenced a journey seeking out Ruby knowledge. Alas, I was the sole Ruby developer in a very small town. Armed with a laptop and microphone, my quest took led me on a journey through the interwebs of pair programming and google plus hangouts. Come along as our my story unfolds. Along the way, we'll go over the dark secrets of navigating the windows and panes of the mystical TMUX and Vim. We'll discuss the anti patterns to avoid and the patterns to follow that can ensure success. We'll discuss tricks and techniques both novices and intermediate pair programming teams will benefit from.

Presented by Jim Nanney

events.name: Automation is Awesome (with Chef)
events.description: How automation tools like Chef can help you build 'infrastructure as code' to help you achieve a platform agnostic continuous delivery pipeline. Â Presented by Marc Cenac.

events.name: Genetic Algorithms with Benjamin Eckel
events.description: Benjamin Eckel will be discussing how to apply genetic algorithms to problems using code examples.

events.name: Introducing RubyMotion - The Cool Way to Build iOS Apps
events.description: Join Gant Laborde into the amazing world of Ruby for iOS. Â We'll cover everything needed in order to build a simple iPhone application.

events.name: A Practical Introduction to Scala
events.description:
A Practical Introduction to ScalaÂ 

An overview of some of the features of Scala, what I like about it, some of the gotchas, and why you should use it instead of Java when programming for the JVM. I will also show who's using it and how they are using it, as well as introduce some of the popular Scala libraries and web frameworks.

Presented By Bryan Joseph

events.name: An Introduction to PostGIS
events.description:
An Introduction to PostGIS

This talk will cover the basics of dealing with geospatial data inÂ PostGIS, including using and defining projections, loading andÂ creating vector data, and an overview of the geospatial operationsÂ provided by PostGIS.

Â 

Presented ByÂ Clayton Parker Coleman

events.name: Linux Containers and YOU
events.description:
Linux Containers and YOU

This talk will discuss the use of Linux Containers as an alternative to other more heavy-weight virtualization schemes with VMs. Topics covered:

â¢Â What is LXC and how does it compare to traditional virtualization

â¢Â Using the linux lxc-package

â¢Â lxc and vagrant -- quick and easy dev environment setup with vagrant-lxc

â¢Â Deploying pre-provisioned lxc-containers instead of code

Presented by Michael (Mikey) Owings.

events.name: Binary Insecurity: Exploiting and Protecting Application Binaries
events.description:
Binary Insecurity: Exploiting and Protecting Application Binaries

What is a buffer overflow and what are the ramification of a stack smash? What does it look like when attackers exploit software vulnerabilities and what does exploitable code look like? How can developers and systems administrators better defend against potential attack vectors?

This presentation by Joshua Penton will cover the basics of exploiting application binaries with live demonstration and explanation of several attack vectors along with solutions for protecting against the vulnerabilities.

events.name: Elixir = Erlang |> Ruby
events.description:
Elixir = Erlang |> Ruby

Elixir is a new functional language with a Ruby-like syntax that targets the same virtual machine as Erlang. With it you can write highly scalable, fault tolerant, concurrent and distributed applications. This presentation will discuss it's short history, some of the language features, some of the libraries and tools available, and why you should give it a try.

Presented byÂ Bryan Joseph

events.name: Chrome Dev Tools for the Uninitiated
events.description:
Chrome Dev Tools for the Uninitiated

As anyone who has done any web development for any length of time can tell you, web development can be hugely frustrating. Â If you've ever done the "Load page, check it in the browser, add alert to the javascript, save, reload page" cycle, this presentation will help tremendously. If you've used the Chrome Developer Tools before, you'll likely pick up a few new tricks as well.

Either way, we'll leave the old habits behind and speed your development through the use of some of Chrome's best development tools and workflows.

Presented by Jim Nanney

events.name: How We Use GitHub to Continuously Integrate GitHub
events.description:
How We Use GitHub to Continuously Integrate GitHub

Presented by Ben Lavender

events.name: Reuseable Charts with D3.js
events.description:
Reuseable Charts with D3.js

I'll be introducing D3.js, a fantastic library for compelling, custom data-driven visualizations. It provides a wealth of abstraction for composing svgs in the DOM, but is geared towards one-off visuals. I'll be taking a look at how we transform d3.js into reusable components.

Presented by Matthew Shwery

events.name: The Case For Crepe: API Design and an Introduction to Crepe
events.description:
The Case For Crepe: API Design and an Introduction to Crepe

Kurtis will be discussing API design and giving an introduction to the Ruby minimalist API framework Crepe.

Presented by Kurtis Rainbolt-Greene

events.name: IRC-Driven Development with Phergie
events.description:
IRC-Driven Development with Phergie

Despite being of legal drinking age, IRC is a technology that remains in active use today. While it was only ever intended to provide a chat server protocol, it's become capable of providing a communal REPL for teams of developers. Enter Phergie, a PHP-based IRC bot designed to service the PHP community. Originally released in 2008, it is now in its third major revision. This presentation provides an introduction to using and developing custom plugins for Phergie that will maximize your development team's productivity by automating tedious tasks and broadcasting useful data.

Presented byÂ Matthew Turland (Phergie Lead Developer)

events.name: Building Web Apps with AngularJS
events.description:
Building Web Apps with AngularJS

This talk will focus on building non-trivial web apps using AngularJS. We'll explore the core ideas of AngularJS, look at some common hang-ups, and share lessons learned from building large web apps with AngularJS. Iâll do my best to cater the talk to the experience level of the audience.

Presented by Rob Schley

events.name: Logging with ELK (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana)
events.description:
Logging with ELK (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana)

We'll have a look at some of the logging-pipeline architectures supported by Logstash and Elasticsearch, and walk through building out some dashboards in Kibana. Â  You'll leave with a pleasant sense of clarity and a spring in your step knowing what Kibana is set up to, and not to do.

Presented by Colin Gagon

events.name: CoffeeBoard - Raspberry Pi website powered LED Scroller
events.description:
CoffeeBoard - Raspberry Pi website powered LED ScrollerÂ 

Are you new to the Raspberry Pi? Â Join Gant Laborde as he dives into setting up a Raspberry Pi to scroll user submitted content.

Presented by Gant Laborde

events.name: Geospatial Visualization in the Browser: An Overview
events.description:
Geospatial Visualization in the Browser: An Overview

We'll take a high level overview of the tools available for creating geospatial visualizations in the browser. I'll introduce you to some tools you've probably seen before and some tools you probably haven't seen. We'll cover strengths and weaknesses, some example implementations, basic use cases, and known limitations.

Presented by Rob Schley

events.name: Metaprogramming JavaScript
events.description:
Metaprogramming JavaScript

A presentation on the SpiderMonkey (JavaScript) Abstract Syntax Tree, it's origin, the AST definitions and how to parse JavaScript code to create it. Also, tools and libraries will be discussed that one can use or that work with one's code at the AST level for code analysis or even creating custom syntax.

Presented by Bryan Joseph

events.name: Relational Databases: A Practical Introduction
events.description:
Relational Databases: A Practical Introduction

This talk will cover the basics of what a relational database is, and how to retrieve and update information in it. The talk will focus on Postgres-dialect SQL, and will include many practical examples of CRUD operations, Joins, Aggregate Queries and Subselects. The talk will include a lab where we will query a Postgres database containing information from IMDB in search of interesting movie trivia

Please have the latest version of pgAdmin installed if you want to participate in the lab!

Presented by Parker Coleman

events.name: How to Undo in Git
events.description:
How to Undo in Git

Git is a powerful distributed version control system that is popular in the open source community. The focus of this talk will be the various ways to use git to undo changes and go back to previous states of the code. There are many methods available but depending on the exact situation some have clear advantage over others. After a brief introduction to some basic commands we will go over these various methods and their use case scenarios. Rather than a lecture, this will be an interactive lesson, it is recommended that you bring a computer with git installed if youâd like to participate.

Presented by Jacqui Nelson

events.name: Rust for the JavaScript Generation
events.description:
Rust for the JavaScript Generation

Compiled low-level languages like C have always been kind of a "Magic Black Box" to programmers that grew up with dynamic languages like JS, C#, Python, and Ruby. Partly because there are many arcane pitfalls lurking in the shadows for the neophytes, and some even trip up old hands as well. Enter Rust, a drop-in replacement for C, which promises to remedy many of those old pain points while also providing all the convenience features the dynamic language generation have come to love and demand.

Presented by Steve Price

events.name: Running a Big Data Platform on AWS
events.description:
Running a Big Data Platform on AWS

Iâll start with a general overview of big data and common tools (like Hadoop) that are used to process big data. Â Then Iâll share some advantages of using AWS and look at the implementation weâre currently using at Unified. Â Iâll explore how weâre using Kafka, Spark, and AWS to build our data pipeline.

Presented by Marc Cenac

events.name: An Introduction to ES6, the next version of Javascript
events.description:
An Introduction to ES6, the next version of Javascript

You've heard of javascript, you may even have wrote some inline in one of your web pages. In this talk, we'll walk through a brief history of javascript, and dive into the new features brought about in this latest version, called ES6 or ES2015. We'll cover a lot of the new syntax, and ways it can make developing easier. We won't cover all aspects, but what we don't have time for, I'll make sure you walk away knowing where to look.

The only pre-requisites for this is a knowledge of any programming language. If you understand javascript's "this" it will be helpful, but I will cover it in the one place it is important in this talk.

Presented by Jim Nanney

events.name: Phoenix - The Elixir Web Framework
events.description:
Phoenix - The Elixir Web Framework

Phoenix is the web framework for Elixir. Phoenix promises high performance, scalable, real-time applications and delivers. Maybe most important is it was built with developer productivity in mind and is a joy to work with. In this presentation, I will show and tell you why you should consider Phoenix for your next project.

Presented by Bryan Joseph

events.name: Adventures in Refactoring
events.description:
Adventures in Refactoring

At GitHub, we've refactored a lot of projects in the last couple of years, some big, some small. In this talk, we'll cover some techniques for different kinds of refactorings and some nifty Ruby libraries we've made to help us out. Then we'll spend a bit of time pondering why language designers aren't helping us out with this everyday task.

Presented by Ben Lavender

events.name: The Go Language - Concurrent programming for everybody
events.description:
The Go Language - Concurrent programming for everybody

Google's Go language has seen an explosion of growth over the last couple of years, offering dead simple concurrency and high performance executable generation with a low cognitive barrier to entry for programmers used to more dynamic Â languages like Python, Ruby and Javascript.

We'll be exploring Go through simple examples, discussing advantages and drawbacks of the language.Â  If you're considering using Node, Python or Ruby for your next project, you may want to come on down and see if Go might be a better fit.

Presented by Michael Owings

events.name: Be the Es6iest
events.description:
Be the Es6iest

Yes, Javascript the Good Parts is largely about the bad parts of Javascript, but there are good ones! Especially when hitting your stride with ES6 using jspm to make everything transparently simple. Arrow functions, the spread operator, deconstruction, and simplified objects. Learn the good parts with a live-coding session creating a realistic multi-state widget.

Presented by George Mauer

events.name: A Tour of React Native
events.description:
A Tour of React Native

Join Gant Laborde as we venture into the wild world of native applications with Facebookâs React. Â  React Native is an exploding trend that allows a high code reuse for mobile applications in native speed.

Presented by Gant Laborde

events.name: Data for Web Applications
events.description:
Data for Web Applications

We love making web apps but sometimes when it comes to the data, we just donât know where to start. This month at gnocode, we will discuss how to think about data models to support great web applications. Sia interviewed developers at nine different companies to understand how they approach data, and will share the results plus practical tips for new to intermediate developers.

Presented by SiaÂ Karamalegos

events.name: ChatOps in 2016
events.description:
ChatOps in 2016

Especially if you're in operations, you've probably have heard of ChatOps. At GitHub, we've been working with them for more than 5 years, and we're continuing to scale these practices. We're creating some guidelines as we learn, and we'd like to share them.

Presented byÂ Ben Lavender

events.name: JavaScript Apps with React Native Ignite
events.description:
JavaScript Apps with React Native Ignite

React Native is popular for a reason. Â If youâre interested in writing mobile apps with JavaScript, youâve got a long but fun road ahead. Â  Gant will be demonstrating React Native with his personal jumpstarter Ignite. Â  Weâll look into this generator for a quickstart, and identify the tools it provides.

Presented by Gant Laborde

events.name: Web App Forensics
events.description:
Web App Forensics

In this talk we'll take a reverse-engineering peek at the design of online collaboration services, like Google Docs, Dropbox Paper, Zoho, etc. The motivation behind the work comes from the need to perform forensic analysis of cloud artifacts, but also shows us a good deal about the design ideas behind these apps and lets us ask some interesting questions, like: What happens when I delete something? Does my typing leave a biometric signature? Why is Microsoft's web stuff so weird?

Vassil Roussev is a Professor of Computer Science at UNO and works on cyber security and digital forensics; in his spare time, he likes to listen toÂ gnocodeÂ talks by former students.

events.name: History of the Web and How It Is How We Got Where We Are
events.description:
History of the Web and How It Is How We Got Where We Are

HTML, CSS, Javascript - web developers use these tools daily but don't understand exactly how they came about. Why is the web so darn weird? The question can be answered in a historical context. This talks goes deep with why HTML, CSS, and Javascript are the way that they are, including some predictions of future trends.

Presented by George Mauer

events.name: Elixir + Phoenix + ES6 + React
events.description:
Elixir + Phoenix + ES6 + React

In this presentation Cory will give an overview of Elixir, Phoenix, ES6, and React, and how to use them to create a simple single page sudoku web application. Part slide presentation and part demo, the talk will also involve a brief discussion on how to quickly get up and running using Docker and Docker Compose.

Presented by Cory Fabre

events.name: Building Composable Abstractions
events.description:
Building Composable Abstractions

Do you want to create robust and composable abstractions? Conal Elliott's Denotational Design is an iterative process to define the essence of a domain and build in composability. The resulting abstractions lead to more robust code at the core of your application and can give your business a competitive advantage. This is the process that created Functional Reactive Programming. We will apply this process to the Processing.js graphics library to develop a composable vector graphics system.

Presented by Eric Normand

events.name: Just Use Forms Already
events.description:
Just Use Forms Already

Everything old is new again! HTML forms - which we all used years ago have gone out of vogue in favor of model-binding, uni-directional data-flow, Relay, FRP, and every other thing under the sun. But they are still around, and they are still useful. With a few minor tweaks indeed, they are extremely useful even in modern web application. This talk covers the why and how of using forms in modern web applications.

Presented by George Mauer

events.name: Using Elixirscript
events.description:
Using Elixirscript

This talk will discuss ways of using Elixirscript today. It will start with a short introduction into what is Elixirscript and how it works. The rest of the talk will focus on what is currently possible, JavaScript interoperability, use with Phoenix projects, Elixir code sharing, and finally a future roadmap.

Presented by Bryan Joseph (Elixirscript creator)

events.name: Mobile Apps Easy - Ignite 2.0
events.description:
Mobile Apps Easy - Ignite 2.0

Building a platform, the story, the party, the architecture. Â Using Facebookâs React Native, you can tie in with the Ignite Plugin Co-Pilot, to build in a modular fashion.

Presented by Gant Laborde

events.name: Distributed Systems in Elixir: Climbing the Ladder of Abstraction
events.description:
Distributed Systems in Elixir: Climbing the Ladder of Abstraction

Navigating the world of concurrency in Elixir and Erlang, we will head down the path of various systems: Erlang VM (processes), concurrency functions, OTP, and distributed processing.

Presented by Ben Eckel

events.name: A Novice Exploration of Elm
events.description:
A Novice Exploration of Elm

In this talk, we will explore Elm: A functional, declarative programming language designed for web-based graphical user interfaces. We will answer such pressing questions as âWhat is Elmâ and âWhy do I need YetAnotherCompiledToJSLanguageâ.

Presented by Devin Villegas

events.name: No REST for the Weary... Introducing GraphQL
events.description:
No REST for the Weary... Introducing GraphQL

RESTful APIs can make fetching data pretty hairy sometimes, but fetching data doesnât have to be so difficult. Enter GraphQLâ¦ the query language where you can ask for exactly what you need with a single HTTP request. Come learn what all the buzz is about!Â 

What is GraphQL? How does it differ from REST? In this session, Iâll answer these questions as well as give you an overview of the ecosystem. Of course, an introduction would not be complete without a demonstration of how to use GraphQL, including queries, resolving, integrating into a front-end app, and more!

Youâll get the most out of this session if youâre familiar with JavaScript and ES6 syntax. Youâll get all the fancy concepts you need through code examples. The last part of the demo will show integration with a React app, but itâs not critical that you know React to learn the fundamentals of GraphQL from this session.

Presented by SiaÂ Karamalegos

events.name: Building a Better API with JSON:API
events.description:
Building a Better API with JSON:API

If youâve implemented API endpoints or consumed APIs it may bug you that every API seems to be different. What if there was a universal standard that made sense? Enter JSON:API, a standard for creating self explaining JSON APIs. Clients built around JSON:API can efficiently cache responses, sometimes eliminating network requests entirely. This session will teach you how you can get started with JSON:API

Presented by Chris Guzman

events.name: 7 Falsehoods Programmers Believe about Place & Time
events.description:
7 Falsehoods Programmers Believe about Place & Time

What if I told you everything you know about location and time was wrong? Geospatial software has come a long way and everything works greatâ¦ that is, until humans join the scene.

By building a historical geography platform with open source tools and challenging our users to collaboratively organize knowledge about the world both spatially and temporally... weâve found that users have a much different view of reality than we anticipated in our database.

Letâs address some assumptions you might be making about the nature of spatiotemporal data. From collection to storage to requests to visualization thereâs a significant disconnect between the data model and user knowledge --- is software rich enough to support the whole story?

Presented by Emily Ashley

events.name: Creating a Useful CLI - the 2017 Experience
events.description:
Creating a Useful CLI - the 2017 Experience (featuring Node, TypeScript and more)

The more things change, the more they stay the same. Using massive tool-chains to build and automate your projects is great, until thereâs a missing part. Join Gant Laborde as he reviews the process of refining a âParts Checkerâ CLI in 2017 technology. Introducing Solidarity built with Gluegun.

Presented by Gant Laborde

events.name: CQRS - Lite and Otherwise
events.description:
CQRS - Lite and Otherwise

A popular buzzword, CQRS is often misunderstood and more often misused. Less of an architecture, than a set of related techniques and an architectural flavor, it is an important and powerful technique to have in your arsenal. Here we will discuss traditional CQRS, break it down to its essence, and discuss a lightweight alternative by which an application can be created without much of the overhead and a straightforward transition path to a fully CQRS style.

Presented by George Mauer

events.name: Front-End Performance Still Matters
events.description:
Front-End Performance Still Matters

Help! My app bundle is 5MB! My users are angry that my app is so slow! Itâs easy to forget that performance matters when we are under pressure to deliver features quickly. What things should we always do versus only do when performance is slow? What data should we use to inform our decisions? From code splitting, lazy loading, and tree shaking to image optimization and store architecture, come learn how you can deliver a better experience to your users with high-performing front-end apps. This talk uses Webpack and ES6 but is library-agnostic (React, Angular, Vue, etc.).

Presented by Sia Karamalegos

events.name: Elm Game Dev with SVG
events.description:
Elm Game Dev with SVG

After going through a quick introduction into Elm, we will explore how to use it to create a simple game.

Presented by Cory Fabre

events.name: AI is Terribly Great and Apache Cassandra Fundamentals
events.description:
We will have two 30 minute presentations for this meeting:

AI is Terribly Great

Come see how the barrier to entry to working with AI is lower than you thought. In this interactive session, Sia will show us how to build a bot using some of the fun tools out there like text recognition, sentiment analysis, text-to-speech, and translate.

Presented byÂ Sia Karamalegos

Apache Cassandra Fundamentals

Distributed systems come with distributed problems. Learn about the basic issues that come into designing a distributed database and how they are dealt with in Apache Cassandra.

Presented byÂ Russell Spitzer

events.name: Field Guide to Assessing Cyber Security
events.description:
Field Guide to Assessing Cyber Security

Learn the basics of what DevOps should consider when assessing cyber security.

Presented by Sonny Smith

events.name: React and Storybook Driven Development?
events.description:
Discuss a particular take on using ReactJs with the new and improved React Contexts feature, and how to structure your code in a way to get the most out of StorybookJs for a dynamic development experience.

Presented by George Mauer

The meetup for this month will be located in the Three Key venue in the Ace Hotel. http://threekeysnola.com/

events.name: Hint, hint, perf matters!
events.description:
Hint, hint, perf matters!

Resource hints are a cool way to play tricks with latency to load web applications faster. Come learn all about resource hints as we apply them to Google Fonts to make them faster.

Presented by Sia Karamalegos

events.name: Getting Started With Go
events.description:
Getting Started With Go

Go is a language thatâs been growing in popularity over the last few years and has become the backbone of many of the major cloud services we all depend on today. Letâs talk about some of the basics of Go and do a somewhat live demo of building some applications with it to see what the fuss is all about.

Presented by Scott Hendrick

events.name: How Recurly runs our developer ecosystem
events.description:
This talk will be about Recurly's experience providing an API as a product. We'll be discussing decisions that have gone well and decisions that have haunted us for nearly a decade. We'll be covering topics such as:

* Versioning
* Client Libraries
* Documentation
* Performance

Presented by Ben Eckel

events.name: Cloud Study Jam: Google Cloud Essentials & IoT
events.description:
Want to get started on Google Cloud Platform (GCP) or the Internet of Things (IoT), but don't know where to begin? Join us for our first Cloud Study Jam!

You get official Google training, a $55+ value, free of charge. Together we'll work through several Google Cloud labs on the essentials of GCP and IoT where you will get hands-on experience.

Then after our live session, you will have free access to more labs you can finish at home. Complete all labs in the quest and earn a Google-hosted badge for your online profile, and additional 30 days access to the training platform to compete any labs you want.

In addition, deploy an eligible action on Google Assistant and earn $200 monthly Google Cloud credit and an Assistant t-shirt! Learn more here: https://developers.google.com/actions/community/

Bring a laptop, HEADPHONES, and charger (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed. Donât forget your charger.

We'll use the Nola dev's Slack group for live communications during the event. If you're not already a member, sign up here: https://nola-slackin.herokuapp.com. Join the #cloud-study-jam channel.

events.name: Kubernetes: So What and What Else
events.description:
GDG New Orleans is a monthly meeting where developers can present on any topic related to technology and software development. This month's talk is:

Kubernetes: So What and What Else
The latest buzzword. You see it everywhere. What is it? Why all the hype? Kubernetes has certainly been the latest shiny object in software development and delivery lately. It certainly is an advancement in application packaging, deployment, operations, and application mobility, but it doesn't solve the entire application delivery problem. Join us to learn the basics of Kubernetes and its relationship to Docker Containers. Discover what all the hype is about and how it can help you delivery better applications. But beware, Kubernetes is not the entire solution.

This month's talk is presented by:

John Boudreaux, better known as Boosey (Boo-see), serves as the Chief Innovation Officer for Distribution Market, North America, for IBM. He has helped to develop and bring to market technologies and methodologies focusing on Application and Cognitive Computing Innovation Methodology. He works with clients to help them understand the process and technologies which every company can use to create solutions that are not just inventive, but achieve the desired business outcomes. Boosey has been on the leading edge of technology for his entire career beginning in the IBM Lab in 1987 where he worked on advanced technology that produced the first market successful visual development environment, and through the years has continued to be on the leading edge which now includes containerization, cognitive computing and artificial intelligence, cloud, Blockchain, and IoT.

We look forward to seeing you at our event! If you're interested in giving a talk let us know.

events.name: Diving into WebAssembly
events.description:
GDG New Orleans is a monthly meeting where developers can present on any topic related to technology and software development. This week we present:

Diving into WebAssembly

WebAssembly is the exciting new alternative to Javascript. With WebAssembly, you can write code in any language, and it runs in the web browser at near native speeds. Join us as we talk about the basics and walk through an example.Languages that can compile to WebAssembly include C, C++, Rust, Java, C#, Python, Elixir, and Go. WebAssembly is an open standard, supported by all modern browsers.Compared to Javascript, WebAssembly can provide greater performance and lower file sizes. Also, emerging features like multithreading provide new capabilities that haven't been possible in the web browser before.

Hosted by Charles Babbitt, Founder & CEO of Blockpad (blockpad.net)

And don't forget our DevFest Conference we're hosting in October! Tickets are available now. https://devfest2019.gdgneworleans.com/

events.name: Predict and experiment your way to app success with Firebase
events.description:
GDG New Orleans & Women Techmakers present Shagun Rawat from Google talking about Firebase:

The talk will focus on how developers can harness the power of Firebase, to build effective data-driven monetization and engagement strategies on the way to a successful app. Building a great app is only half the battle, as operating an app requires actively managing changes and features based on user behavior. The motivation of the talk is to help developers navigate these decisions with data-driven models rather than hope-driven strategies.

Shagun is a software/ML engineer for Firebase at Google. She helps developers experiment with their apps by helping them understand user behavior over time. Prior to that, she received her PhD in Machine Learning from University of California Merced working on data driven modeling of dynamic systems.

GDG New Orleans is a monthly meeting where developers can present on any topic related to technology and software development. Have a talk idea? Let us know!

events.name: TDD With No More Tears
events.description:
Unit testing is hard to get right. Are you testing too much? Too little? How do you write tests that aren't a waste of time? Isn't testing supposed to enable refactoring? Then why do they seem to be in the way? What's this BDD thing I keep hearing about? Do we need to learn yet another tool?

This talk goes deep into the philosophy behind unit testing in general and test-driven development in particular. We will discuss how to keep things simple yet useful and showcase a strategy for writing tests that achieve our goals without wasting everybody's time.

Presented by George Mauer, Director of Development with Surge Consulting Group.

events.name: Modern JavaScript for Modern Browsers
events.description:
MODERN JAVASCRIPT FOR MODERN BROWSERS, presented by Sia Karamalegos

More developers are starting to understand that web performance matters. From higher mobile search rankings to bottom-line revenue impacts, performance can make or break your web app. However, fixing performance can feel like a quagmire of expert-level nuanced understanding on so many topics. What would you think if I told you you could cut your JavaScript bundle size up to 50% by doing one thing only? Nearly 90% of worldwide web traffic runs on modern browsers, but we're transpiling all of our JavaScript down to ES5. That transpilation has a cost.

In this talk, we'll learn about differential serving, or serving modern bundles to modern browsers and legacy, transpiled bundles to older browsers. We'll talk about strategies, what to watch out for, and how to implement it using webpack. This talk is framework agnostic, and it's best if you have at least a basic understand of JavaScript.

upcoming.name: GDG New Orleans Monthly Meeting
upcoming.description:
This month we're hosting two speakers.

Stan Williams, a Senior Solutions Engineer at Sauce Labs will be presenting "Simple Sauce: Getting Started with Automated Testing"

Sia Karamalegos will talk about Responsive Images for the Web. Images account for 50% of the bytes downloaded to load a website. How can you make sure that your users only download the smallest image necessary while preserving image quality? In this talk, we'll focus on the underlying concepts in HTML and CSS for serving responsive images, which you can take with you no matter which tool you use.Which file formats suit which image types best? How can you use art direction in images to show the best image for a viewport layout? Come learn about this and more!
